newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Low grades threaten Mhangura copper mine.
newsitem.headline: Low grades threaten Mhangura copper mine.

text.p: Zimbabwe's Mhangura Copper Mine can no longer be mined economically because it has exhausted its higher grade ore, the state-owned Herald newspaper said on Monday.
"The good-quality grade is exhausted. We are just scratching for the available low-grade ore to keep the mine going," deputy mines minister Zenzo Nsimbi told the Herald at the weekend.
The mine currently produces ore with 0.72 percent copper content, down from grades as high as 2.46 percent.

President Robert Mugabe's cash-strapped government, in an effort to keep Mhangura afloat and save hundreds of jobs, has approved Z$230 million (U.S.$20.4 million) as guarantee for the mine to source credit, conduct explorations and pay off some of its creditors.
Industry experts, including the Zimbabwe Mining Development Corporation which owns the mine, say it should close down in the face of falling international copper prices.
Mhangura produced 907 tonnes of copper in the first three months of 1997, down from 1,283 tonnes in the same period last year, chamber of mines figures show.
